prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
Spectral setup: We require maximum sensitivity to 870um continuum emission, so we use the standard spectral setup for continuum observations with 7.5 GHz of bandwidth and the standard representative frequency of 343.00 GHz (most of our targets do not have spectroscopic redshifts, so there is no need to tune the receivers to a particular frequency to observe e.g. CO).
Required spatial resolution: Our primary science goals are two-fold. First, measure the morphologies of the unlensed DSFGs in our sample and search for evidence of kpc-size clumps. Second, obtain 100 - 500 pc resolution imaging of lensed DSFGs in our sample. Our sample comprises targets at z = 1.5 - 3.5. For this redshift range, our desired physical resolutions correspond to angular resolutions of ~0.1". This can only be achieved with the longest baselines available in Cycle 2. Figure 4 presents CASA simulations that show the importance of the factor of 4 improvement in spatial resolution provided by our proposed observations, both for unlensed and lensed DSFGs.
Largest angular structure: Some of the galaxies in our sample are extended on scales of 1" - 2" (in part as a result of strong lensing). Emission on these size scales will be recovered fully for all of our targets via our existing Cycle 0 870um continuum imaging. There is therefore no need for multi-configuration observations to carry out our science goals.
Sensitivity: First, we address the sensitivity requirements for the unlensed DSFGs in our sample. These have intrinsic flux densities at 870um ranging from 1.5 mJy to 15 mJy. Figure 4 shows CASA simulations of a representative clumpy disk (see science justification for details) with a total flux density at 870um of 5 mJy, a value that would place it near the median value in our sample. The disk has a radius of 0.4" and there are three clumps embedded within it, each of which have radii of 0.05". One clump is located at the center and the other two are located randomly within the disk. The total flux contributed by the clumps is equal to 30% of the flux from the disk. Our requested sensitivity is sufficient to detect two off-center clumps at 5-sigma, as well as the brighter central clump at 10-sigma. Detecting the off-center clumps in the faintest targets in our sample will be more challenging, but we will still have the sensitivity to detect the hallmark signature of a major merger: two equally bright nuclei containing the vast majority of the total flux of the target. In this scenario, each nucleus would have a total flux density of ~0.7 mJy (for the faintest objects in our sample) and would be detected at 7-sigma.
Second, we address the sensitivity requirements for the lensed DSFGs in our sample. These have the brightest apparent 870um flux densities, but also the most complicated morphologies due to the distortions induced by strong lensing. We show in Figure 4 a CASA simulation of our proposed Cycle 2 observations of ADFS07, using as input the best-fit lens model derived from our Cycle 0 data. The lensed features from this relatively simple model are detected at >10-sigma. Detection of fainter features than those identified in the best-fit Cycle 0 model will allow us to test more realistic models for the background source, thus providing true morphologies for these objects.
Finally, lens modeling involves a large number of parameters, some of which are degenerate with each other. Modern computational techniques can overcome this obstacle on reasonable timescales. Using the method described in Bussmann et al. (2013), we obtain good fits to our ALMA Cycle 0 data in ~1 day of computing time on a MacBook Air laptop for each source. With access to supercomputer facilities at the Smithsonian Institution and at Cornell University with a factor of ~1000 more cores than a MacBook Air, we expect to overcome the computational obstacles associated with modeling our proposed Cycle 2 data.

prp:ObsProposal.prp:abstract: Wide-field surveys with Herschel are excellent tools to identify dusty star-forming galaxies (DSFGs). Our team has obtained 0.5" resolution 870um imaging with ALMA in Cycle 0 for a sample of 27 Herschel DSFGs from the HerMES survey that covers a wide range in intrinsic luminosity (in part due to strong gravitational lensing). These data are sufficient to determine which are lensed and which are blends of multiple sources, but little else--for nearly all of our targets, Gaussian profiles successfully reproduce the data. Higher resolution imaging is critically needed to search for morphological features on sub-kpc scales and test competing theories for the nature of DSFGs. We propose ALMA Cycle 2 0.12" resolution 870um imaging of our Cycle 0 sample of Herschel DSFGs. We will use this unprecendented dataset to search for morphological evidence for either of the two primary physical mechanisms thought to power DSFGs: violent disk instability and major mergers. We will leverage the large size of the sample and broad range of IR luminosity to test the theoretical expectation that the transition from disk instability to mergers occurs at the median IR luminosity in our sample.
prp:ObsProposal.prp:relatedProposals:
A companion proposal (PI: Bussmann) targets a subset of the sample in this proposal for a redshift search in the 3mm atmospheric window. Both proposals stand on their own merits, but naturally each will benefit from the other if both are approved.
A second companion proposal (PI: Riechers) also targets Herschel dusty star-forming galaxies at high resolution, but focuses on a sample of the brightest 10-14 strongly lensed sources with known spectroscopic redshifts in windows that are suitable for [CII] observations. Two of our targets overlap with the sample in this companion proposal. Each proposal stands on its own merits, but if both proposals are successful, we will use this overlap to search for morphological differences between the two frequencies probed by our proposals: 345 GHz (this proposal) and ~400 GHz (Riechers).
Another related proposal requests 0.12" 870um imaging of Herschel DSFGs (PI: Eales). That proposal includes only the brightest, strongly lensed Herschel DSFGs and emphasizes different science goals than our proposal.
prp:ObsProposal.prp:previousProposals: Our team obtained ALMA Cycle 0 observations of the sample in this proposal. These data are critical to the success of our proposed Cycle 2 observations.
prp:ObsProposal.prp:scientificCategoryString: Cosmology and the High Redshift Universe

prp:PrincipalInvestigator.prp:organisation: Smithsonian Astrophysical Observatory, Harvard-Smithsonian Center for Astrophysics

prp:CoInvestigator.prp:organisation: School of Physics and Astronomy, Cardiff University
Blackett Laboratory, Imperial College of Science, Technology and Medicine
